attributes.text: Commands can be used to globally define keyboard shortcuts. They could also be used to assign a execution of a command sequence to multiple widgets. It is possible to use the same Command in a MenuButton and ToolBarButton for example.

Shortcuts can be composed of optional modifier keys Control, Alt, Shift, Meta and a non modifier key. If no non modifier key is specified, the second paramater is evaluated. The key must be separated by a + or - character. Examples: Alt+F1, Control+C, Control+Alt+Delete
Fired on change of the property {@link #enabled}.
Fired on change of the property {@link #icon}.

Fired on change of the property {@link #value}.
Fired when the command is executed. Sets the “data” property of the event to the object that issued the command.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property enabled.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #_applyEnabled}.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property shortcut.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #_applyShortcut}.
Object which issued the execute event
Fire the “execute” event on this command.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property enabled with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #enabled}.

Check whether the (computed) value of the boolean property enabled equals true.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #enabled}.
Whether the property equals true.

Resets the user value of the property enabled.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.
